key_facts: COVID-19 is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The most common symptoms are fever, chills, and sore throat.
Most people recover without needing hospital treatment. People with severe symptoms should seek medical care immediately.
Over 760 million cases and 6.9 million deaths have been recorded worldwide since December 2019.
Over 13 billion vaccine doses have been administered as of June 2023.

overview.description: COVID-19 is the disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus. It usually spreads between people in close contact.
overview.vaccination: COVID-19 vaccines provide strong protection against severe illness and death. Vaccinated individuals are more likely to experience mild or no symptoms if infected.
overview.high_risk_groups: People over age 60, those with pre-existing conditions like high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, immunosuppression, cancer, and pregnant individuals have a higher risk of severe illness.

less_common_symptoms: Loss or change of sense of taste or smell
severe_symptoms: Persistent pain or pressure in the chest

transmission.description: COVID-19 spreads through close contact between people.
transmission.precautions: Vaccination, wearing masks, and maintaining social distance reduce transmission.

treatment.mild_cases: Most people recover without hospital treatment.
treatment.severe_cases: Immediate medical care is required. Severe illness can lead to death, respiratory failure, sepsis, blood clots, and multi-organ failure.
treatment.long_COVID: Some people continue to experience symptoms after recovery, impacting daily activities.
